block.p: Retailing concepts that spread quickly across the country often come from places like Georgia (Home Depot) or Arkansas (Wal-Mart Stores).
But Mati Weiderpass, a veteran of the Swatch watchmaking company, and Ian Reisner, a Wall Street executive, started in Manhattan's SoHo with just a single Watch World store six years ago.
Retailing concepts that spread quickly across the country often come from places like Georgia (Home Depot) or Arkansas (Wal-Mart Stores).
But Mati Weiderpass, a veteran of the Swatch watchmaking company, and Ian Reisner, a Wall Street executive, started in Manhattan's SoHo with just a single Watch World store six years ago.
They grew to 119 stores, selling casual and inexpensive watches. They also gained a rival: Watch Station, owned by Sunglass Hut, of Coral Gables, Fla.
Earlier this month, Mr. Weiderpass and Mr. Reisner sold their chain to Sunglass Hut for $30 million.
''We didn't want to sell until the timing was right,'' said Mr. Weiderpass.
They plan to stay in New York, as a couple, while they hunt for their next marketable idea.
